Award.AwardTitle: Algorithms, analyses, and model reductions for a class of parametrized systems
Award.AbstractNarration:
The main aim of the project is to develop, implement, and analyze innovative fast and highly accurate algorithms for simulation, model reduction, and quantification of interactions and radiation induced by parametrized configurations comprising a large number of three dimensional particles. The focus is specifically on large systems with hundreds or even thousands of particles in multiscale configurations that arise in atmospheric and biological sciences applications. Even for a fixed set of parameters describing a large configuration,standard iterative algorithms (and acceleration techniques) suffer from computational complexity (and slow convergence). The innovative preconditioned and accelerated iterative algorithms and analyses in this project facilitate a practical approach to efficiently simulate scattering and absorption by (and interactions of) large numbers of particles occurring in atmospheric and biological sciences. Development of very efficient algorithms for electromagnetic scattering and absorption by a single three dimensional particle is essential to simulate interactions in large configurations.

Atmospheric aerosols affect Earth's energy budget directly by scattering and absorbing radiation, and indirectly by modifying the amount of cloud and the radiative properties of clouds. One of the highest priority tasks is to advance the ability to model aerosol-cloud-precipitation interaction in climate models. The key to quantifying and reducing uncertainty about the impact of aerosols is to understand the scattering, absorption, and interaction properties of large configurations of particles well enough to accurately replicate them in the full climate models. A technically related problem arises in medical diagnostics where a high priority task is to understand how a laser beam interacts with a large number of red blood cells (erythrocytes). The focus of the project is to implement the computational mathematics component of these high priority recommendations. The project includes training of graduate and undergraduate students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Major goals of the project are concerned with the development, implementation, and analysis of  innovative computational tools, at several stages, for efficient offline/online simulation and quantification of uncertainties in  a class of single and multiple processes deterministic, stochastic, and parametrized  mathematical models.

Innvoative research work were carried out in the following research topics:

  • High-order, stochastic, and model reduction algorithms for scattering and absorption by multiple particle two dimensional  configurations.
  • Approximations and analysis for efficient evaluation of wideband frequency  integrals on spheres for three dimensional low to high-frequency wave scattering simulations.

  • Analysis and simulation of electromagnetic wave propagation in three dimensional piecewise constant inhomogeneous media. 

  • Analysis and high-order algorithms  for a class of processes in  three dimensions induced by conducting and superconducting surfaces.

  • Fast algorithm for simulation of interaction of  waves between large number of three dimensional particles and efficient simulation in deterministic configurations.
  • Hybrid and high-order high performance computing  algorithms and sensitivity analysis for large stochastic configurations.

The project includes training of graduate and undergraduate students. Personal collaboration with women and minority students enrolled in investigator’s courses such as parallel scientific computing  enhanced broader participation of under-represented groups. 

During the entire three year life of the award (July 2013 to June 2015), the PI submitted 19 research articles (with over 300 pages) to several international journals and conference proceedings, that include five articles submitted recently to international journal, based on the work completed during the last stages of the award. These five articles are currently under review; six articles were published in peer-reviwed international conference proceedings and eight of the 19 articles have already been published in highly ranked international journal. 

The journal articles have been published in: Journal Mathematical Analysis and Applications (JMAA);  SIAM J. Scientific Comuting (SISC); Journal of Quantitative Spectroscopy and Radiative Transfer (JQSRT); Advances in Computational Mathematics (ACM); Australian and New Zealand Industrial and Applied Mathematics Journal (ANZIAMJ); Journal of Spectral Theory (JST); Applied Numerical Mathematics (ANM) and BIT Numerical Mathematics (BIT-NM). 

Over the last three years, the PI gave over thirty presentations in several international conferences and universities in over ten countries, promoting the innvoative research work funded through the NSF award. Such presentations will have substantial impact among future young and under-represented research in various parts of the world.
